title: 110_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" and includes reforms to the USERRA complaint process. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. The Secretary must notify complainants of their rights within 5 days and provide technical assistance upon request. Section 4322 of title 38, United States Code is amended to require the Secretary to complete actions on complaints within 90 days. Referrals to the Attorney General or special counsel must be expedited within 15 days of receiving a request. The Secretary must refer complaints to the Attorney General promptly, within 15 days of receiving a request. The Attorney General must notify representation within 45 days of receiving a referral. The Attorney General and Special Counsel must make a decision within 45 days of receiving a referral to represent a person and notify them accordingly. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR USERRA ENFORCEMENT. Expansion of reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement includes amending Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code to require the Secretary to report on the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment. The Secretary and the Secretary of Defense must report on cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve. This includes cases related to disabilities and the number of each type of disability. The Secretary and the Secretary of Defense must report on cases involving individuals seeking employment or reemployment through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, including details on disabilities. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit quarterly reports to Congress and other relevant parties on this matter. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report should include the number of cases where the Secretary did not meet certain requirements regarding referrals for employment or reemployment through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The reports should detail cases where referrals for employment or reemployment were not made within the required timeframes by the Secretary, Attorney General, or Special Counsel. The Secretary is also required to ensure uniform categorization of data for these reports. The Secretary must coordinate with other relevant departments to ensure uniform categorization of data in reports required under section 4332. The amendments made by this section will apply to all future reports. The amendments made by this section will apply to all future reports required under section 4332, reviewed by the Secretary, the Secretary of Defense, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. Effective Date: The amendments shall apply after the enactment of this Act.
